title: @Lore Team: What are your thoughts on a "totally evil bastard" character?
body:
What do I mean by that? Think Kefka from FF6. Not a single redeeming quality to him, or any way you can feel sorry for his circumstances. Guy's just one evil sonnovab!tch.

Or Yuki Terumi from Blazblue. Guy makes being evil look good. And that laugh of his? Epic.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=j65pU6h1xoY

I know you guys hate one-dimensional characters, but that doesn't mean you can't have them. A completely evil villain-type would definitely show some contrast to the others in the roster, all whom have SOMETHING to make them more likable. But we honestly need someone who EVERYONE would want to beat the sh!t out of (besides Teemo).

I find this exact trope, "an evil villain that is smart and charismatic, but still thoroughly sadistic and evil" to be *horrendously* boring. It's basically wish-fulfillment of Mary Sue degrees.

Evil, by itself, is not a flaw, which means that villains need to have flaws just as much as heroes do. And flaws are defined as **traits that actively impede a character**.

It's fine to have charismatic villains, or clever villains, or both at the same time, but they must have some type of flaw that actively sabotages them in the eyes of the audience. If the flaws that you picked are things that the narrative portrays as "endearing" rather than actively harmful, it's not an actual flaw (this is why it's so common to give main characters the 'clumsy' trait and pass it off as a flaw, only in 99% of the stories, that trait is there to make them look endearing. Clumsiness as a true flaw makes the reader go "OH MY F%$#ING GOD MAIN CHARACTER CAN YOU F%$#ING STOP BEING SO F%$#ING CLUMSY FOR ONE F%$#ING MINUTE!" when the main character drops something incredibly important from his butterfingers at a crucial time).

Smart and charismatic "bastard" villains are made deliberately flawless as a way for the audience to project themselves into them and have a wish-fulfilment fantasy of being a triumphant, unfettered ubermensch. I would not like to see them in any story, much less in the videogame I like to play so much.

EDIT: There's also a bit of sexism into this character trope. In general, when this type of villain is a man, he tends to be fawned over and liked, with people going out of their way to excuse his actions and paint him in a sympathetic light. This does not tend to happen in the (extremely rare) cases where the trope goes to a woman instead.

When did I say it had to be a "perfect villain"? I simply meant an "unsympathetic villain", one who you would never have pity for on his/her circumstances.

This villain could have quirks, but that doesn't mean you don't still hate him.

It comes with the trope. The "smart and charismatic bastard" is almost always a flawless villain designed for wish-fulfilment. That may not have been your intention, but it is what the rest of the world has decided it should be.

Note also how you say "quirks", instead of "flaws". That is exactly the type of erroneous thinking that leads into "flawless, perfect villain."

I think it's OK to have some one-dimensional characters. Old WW used to be just that. He was pure chaotic evil and reveled at the sight of destruction and chaos that he caused. Even after losing his intelligence when Soraka cursed him and made it so he could no longer use it to create weapons of mass destruction, he still had not changed and remained the evil psychopath he had always been. That's kinda what I found interesting about old ww which made him very different and unique from all the neutral, semi-sympathetic, or "I'm in it for the money and self-interest" villains there are in LoL. I think they completely changed him with the rewrite. It's not like him to use tricks. He used to be intelligent, but he used his brains to create chemical weapons which *he* could use to satisfy his lust for blood. Now a beast, he can no longer create those weapons and mass murder people, but his bloodlust still remained. 

That was the core of his character. No manner of change or transformation could deter his thirst for blood. 

Imo, trying to change WW so he would repent for his crimes and no longer lust for blood would have been a really huge challenge for Soraka.

Someone who just wants chaos and hates order and progress. But with a past where he actually wanted order and progress, and now knows nothing but to hurt, destroy, blow things up. And he has to be scary, not another veigar. A warrior like nocturne-leesin fusion or a mastermind like swain that'd be great

The best current champ to be that evil bastard, imodo, would be {{champion:27}}.  I had my own retcon idea that would have fixed Singed's long broken story.

Singed could have been an isolated chemistry prodigy who created incredible weapons but, because he was in isolation save for a mentor and Warwick (his ingredient gatherer), did not have the shackles of mercy most other scientists had.  After years/decades of isolation, where Noxus/Zaun used the most powerful weapons ever devised, Singed gets a taste of the outside world from Warwick's transformation and realizes that he's been missing something from his scientific method, observing results.

Casually, Singed kills his mentor with the most powerful weapon he has, blows up his lab and survives, thanks to his mostly artificial body.  He then goes off to find out how effective his weapons are.  Singed is only interested in logging the results of his experiments, not giving one damn about the human cost.
